bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to The [Cuban] Academy of Sciences, August 29, 1955

div1.p: Hench requests from the Academy of Sciences the microfilm of Finlay's daybooks written during the yellow fever investigation. He indicates that he would not be able to complete his book without knowing the contents of these daybooks.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to The [Cuban] Academy of Sciences, August 29, 1955
div1.opener:
August 29, 1955
The President and Counsellors
Academy of Sciences
Habana, Cuba
Gentlemen:
div1.p:
I appreciate very greatly the opportunity to obtain a microfilm of the Finlay day-
books which have been deposited in your library. These will give very important
data to anyone who is interested in the life of this great scientist.

As you know, I am writing a book (and have given and will continue to give lectures)
on the conquest of yellow fever. I have always tried to do full justice to Doctor
Finlay whose magnificent work was quite indispensable. For five or six years, I have
held up the writing of my book until I could have this all-important data on Doctor
Finlay. One simply cannot write on the conquest of yellow fever without knowing
everything possible about Doctor Finlay and his remarkable observations and con-
clusions.

As I wrote to your previous President, when I first made this request, I believe that
one copy of this microfilm should be deposited in your own library just in case any-
thing should happen to the original films and I am asking that such a copy be made
and I should like the privilege of paying for it and presenting it to your library
as a very small token of my appreciation.

When, a few years ago, I told the Surgeon General of the United States Army of these
Finlay data, he was very eager to have a copy of the microfilm in the Library of
the Surgeon General so that it might be available to all American scientists and
historians and also to members of the United States Congress. I have therefore asked
that an extra copy of the microfilm be made available for me so that I may present it
to the Surgeon General.

Because of the intense interest which Dr. Pedro Nogueira has had in the life and ac-
complishments of Doctor Finlay and because it was he who first told me of the day-
books, I should like to present to him also a copy of the microfilm. In other words,
now that you have been so gracious as to grant me permission to have the data micro-
filmed, I should like to have not one but four copies made at my expense: One for
your library, one for the Surgeon General of the United States Army, one for Doctor
Nogueira and one for me, which latter copy will be deposited in the Library of the
Mayo Clinic.
Please accept, dear sirs, my sincere appreciation for your cooperation in this matter.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
